Topic.Title: I want my 40 acres and a mule

Message.Msg: i BOUGHT my 40 acres when I exited the market in 2007. Since I've re-entered in 2009 I've done nothing but lose money. My problem I suppose is investing in companies that require constructive economic activity rather than government spending to thrive. That might have worked with Bill between the Bushes, but not with Great King Obama on the Throne.

Topic.Title: I want my 40 acres and a mule

Message.Msg: Oh, and its 17 Trillion, not 9 Trillion, that we're in the hole. Further you can't attribute it to any one program or policy (except the really really big expenditures, that should have been bond funded), and shouldn't even try. Also, don't go down that road, it's mined. I came to a seriously politically incorrect solution to a statistics assignment and was told I should "find another methodology". A hint that my conclusion would utterly stick in the craw of the person grading it. Regardless of the validity of my data and equations.

Message.Title: NTWK ..... EASY TRIPLE.... BUY NOW !!!
Message.Msg: Don't wait to long !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The "ObamaPhone" thing was a canard. That program existed long ago and just provides basic metro service, no smart phones or #$%$ like that. There's a whole slew of phone programs targeting everyone from rural users to the poor. Like the Rural Electrification Board, no government entity ever truly dies, it just mutates.

Er, mortars are indirect fire weapons . . . who's going to call and adjust your fire? Do you know how to setup and use one (I do) . . . Call and adjust fires? So what good would it do you. I'm all for letting people own military weapons, IF they know how to use, maintain, and safely store and handle them and their ammunition. Until schools are developed for civilians that would mean the heavier stuff would be pretty much the province of us ex-military folk, specifically those that served in the combat arms. I'm qualified with everything from a handgun to up to tank main gun. I'm ALL for that sort of law.

Topic.Title: in the manner of the republicans i'm going to wreck my car now to avoid a possible future wreck!

Message.Msg: Actually if the accelerator is jammed in the full on position, wrecking immediately rather than wrecking later IS the wisest move.

Topic.Title: in the manner of the republicans i'm going to wreck my car now to avoid a possible future wreck!

Message.Msg: And, by the way, the only thing that mattered for Reagan's entire Presidency and most of Bush's was sticking it to the Soviet Union. Making subsequent budget cuts by reducing military forces was done during HW Bush's presidency, cutting to what would be needed in a post Soviet world. The subsequent cuts in our military preparedness were so foolish that when called upon to fulfill just PART of the post Soviet requirement our military almost collapsed. Now we're cutting it further. The reason we're cutting it is that due to wording in Congressional law its about the only thing that Congress is ALLOWED to cut without reworking major entitlement program which, along with debt service, take up the VAST bulk of the Federal Budget. You'll never begin to address the budget until you first take a long hard look at all unearned entitlements and eliminate those that are duplicated programs, or spend too much money to do little to no good. Then we have to look at increasing that rate of return until the programs that are left are those that are effective. Let's take Head Start. Great intentions, but the program doesn't work, and certainly doesn't work well enough to justify its budget, yet Republicans hold it up like its their own grandkid. And what was Bush II thinking adding a Prescription Drug mandate to Medicare? It ended up costing less than what was predicted by its worst detractors, but its still not cheap. It's not just the liberals that like to spend money. Our last "conservative" President spent and acted more like a Wilsonian Democrat, and to have a Socialist follow that is very very reminiscent of the decades between World War One and World War Two. Though, depression aside, they were some interesting decades. I wonder if Obama's upcoming Gun Slam will be this centuries version of Prohibition?

Of course not, lots of qualified vets out there, that's the point. We should be the ones training the civilians so they don't bloody shoot themselves in the feet. You got the tix and wants a job we got openings for instructors. Practical pistol and Texas CHL training. You'd need NRA 50 foot pistol instructor qual's and Texas CHL instructor quals.

Message.Title: E*Trade's Loan Portfolio
Message.Msg: Okay so here are some numbers and basic reasoning on ETFC. They have $10B worth of 1-4 family and 2nd lien/home equity loans on their balance sheet. Market cap is $2.83B. Given the significant bounce off the bottom that housing has gone through in the last year I have to believe that the underlying asset to these loans are up 15-25% which is an "increase" in value of around $2B, about 2/3's of the current market cap. How long will it take for the market to start factoring this into the share price?

Topic.Title: I want my 40 acres and a mule

Message.Msg: **Oh, and its 17 Trillion, not 9 Trillion** Actually it's 9 trillion in welfare expendiatures since it inception. **Regardless of the validity of my data and equations** Find another company to work for...they are not interested in a solution rather an outcome.
They wouldn't let me in the country, too heavily armed for them.

This is one of the primary reasons I bought into ETrade post collapse. The valuation the government required they use to provision against losses underestimated the value of the property itself. Now they are over provisioned and have assets more valuable than previously estimated. The downspike in real estate in most areas (save perhaps Las Vegas, where I have a timeshare, thankfully already paid for), was temporary. Once the speculators left the market taking their losses with them sanity began to return. Couple that with a treasury policy that makes mortgages comparatively cheap right now and you naturally have a housing recovery. Once that happens values of existing properties begin to return and previously "under water" mortgages find themselves in a positive equity situation that may allow them to refinance, etc, etc, etc . . .
That target is short, way short.

I am directly involved in Southern California real estate and can tell you that it's a major bounce off the bottom, easily 25% here. I would love to get a sense for the geographic distribution of the loans. Also hope that management does not do anything dumb like sell the loans below what they are worth. We made it this far and need to hold out for the market to restore what should be a few billion in lost market cap from the loan value recapture alone. Why can't this be a $20 stock in a year?

Message.Title: This why you can't take the liberal media seriously
Message.Msg: This man is clearly suffering from Alzheimer's and needs to retire...Trying to make a moral equivalence of gun owners 2nd amendment rights to defeating the Nazis' is beyond absurd. Bob Schieffer Likens Obama taking on the gun lobby to Hunt for Bin Laden, and Defeating the Nazis. Bob Schieffer somehow topped Chris Matthews during CBS News's special coverage of President Obama's gun control press conference on Wednesday, as he became the worst caricature of a foaming-at-the-mouth cheerleader for the chief executive. Schieffer lauded "one of the best speeches I've ever heard him deliver", and compared Obama's new gun control agenda to Lyndon Johnson's push for civil rights legislation in the 1960s. BOB SCHIEFFER: ...Let's remember: there was considerable opposition when Lyndon Johnson went to the Congress and...presented some of the most comprehensive civil rights legislation in the history of this country. Most people told him he couldn't get it done, but he figured out a way to do it. And that's what Barack Obama is going to have to do...what happened in Newtown was probably the worst day in this country's history since 9/11. We found Osama bin Laden. We tracked him down. We changed the way that we dealt with that problem. Surely, finding Osama bin Laden; surely, passing civil rights legislation, as Lyndon Johnson was able to do; and before that, surely, defeating the Nazis, was a much more formidable task than taking on the gun lobby.

Topic.Title: This why you can't take the liberal media seriously

Message.Msg: He's 75... Maybe he will stroke out soon...

Loan origination is PROFITABLE believe me I'm involved in real estate, E*Trade has hundreds of thousands of wealthy and smart clients, Where things went wrong is they bought for the portfolio billions of loans that were overvalued. The cross selling of loans and other financial products will likely be one of the merger synergies discussed once when expected buyout occurs.

Northern California housing inventory is insanely low, property values have gone up at least 10% in the last 6 months (especially last 3 months) in the area alone from what I hear and see. It will be very interesting to see ETrade's next quarterly report due out on 23rd. BAC earning is due out tomorrow b4 market open,it will tell us a lot.

Topic.Title: Beck ‘historian’: History proves armed elementary kids prevent school shootings

Message.Msg: "You can't argue with the fact that Kennesaw has the lowest crime rate of any city our size in the country," "People all over the country said there would be shootings in the street and violence in homes," he said. "Of course, that wasn't the case." In fact, according to Stephenson, it caused the crime rate in the city to plunge. Kennesaw Historical Society president Robert Jones said following the law's passage, the crime rate dropped 89 percent in the city, compared to the modest 10 percent drop statewide.

HELOCS are the problem. Forget the 1-4 family, it's not that bad. Depending on the loan situation, HELOC have virtually zero recovery value. Etrade has 2X the market cap in HELOC's alone. Paint whatever picture you want, HELOC's originated in 2006/2007 are a bust. You simply have to hope people keep paying and you run off the number for a few more years. After that, then Etrade could improve the earnings profile. 2012 will be a total bust in earnings. A loss in Q4 due to the debt refinance will kill the entire year. You don't have much credibility on W/S when you post an annual loss. Not really much of a turnaround story....yet. You have to get some leadership here with fresh ideas and front run some of the other OLB's and STEAL market share away. Trading/Investing with the young crowd is not cool, they have seen too much carnage to want to jump in right now.

I suggest that the value of the HELOCS are impacts the most with the upturn in the market, also don't discount the psychology of a consumer that has paid for seven years will not be giving up now that the property is going back up in value.

IMO, the continued increase in property values should be a very positive catalyst for e*trade regardless whether it be to the first mortgage or HELOC parts of the portfolio. I am sure everybody will be paying a lot of attention to their latest metrics when they come out.

Message.Title: We Demand Answers Or We Demand Impeachment
Message.Msg: “We don’t know” is simply not an acceptable answer, but Weich is not the first to use it. Attorney General Eric Holder gave the same answer when asked the same question a few weeks before. After so many months of scandal and scrutiny, it seems hard to believe the Attorney General still can’t—or won’t—answer this simple question. As NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre told Fox News’ Lou Dobbs in June, “The administration needs to stop the cover-up,” adding, “Either they were doing this to prop up a political agenda of sending thousands of guns across the border and blaming it on American gun laws . . . or they were completely incompetent.” Either way, those who approved this operation, and all those who should have known about it and failed to stop it, are responsible for the operation’s horrendous outcome. And that certainly includes Attorney General Holder. At the core of this scandal is the effort to politicize BATFE’s law enforcement activities and to take advantage of yet another crisis to achieve a political agenda: the passage of new gun control laws.

Many liberals are considering helping. they are patting themselves on the back and sharing their goodness with anyone who will listen. Saturday morning they will stay in and burn a J. But that won't help them a bit. wyoste, are you still out there?
